Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 11:14AM lemont wrote: Hi, Deb. I'm sorry you're going through so much anxiety right now. Everyone is correct in saying the waiting is the hardest part. (OK, the surgeries and chemo were hard too, but the waiting is right up there.) You're doing the right thing by getting a second opinion from a specialist. When I was going through diagnosis, it helped me stop the "what-if's" by writing down my questions. Somehow things seemed more manageable. If you aren't satisfied with the 2nd opinion, get a 3rd, or a 4th. I wish you the best. Keep us posted. Cinda
Posts.Title: What is considered to be "early detection"? tobyholic lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 12:06PM lemont wrote: Tweety, I decided on a bilat mx even though I only had cancer in one breast. I'm happy with my choice but my reasons won't be your reasons. I, too, was dizzy with all the factors swimming around in my head. I found it tremendously helpful to write down my pros and cons. It really made my choice clear. My surgeon just about went into shock when I told him. Because I had my list with me, I was able to calmly and clearly articulate my reasons. He ended up agreeing that my reasons were valid for me, and the rest is history. Cinda
Posts.Title: Making the Mastectomy Decision Kaidog mikita5

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 06:15PM lemont wrote: You wear your own clothes, no need for a gown. I also took my calendar for making the next appointment(s). When I started chemo, I didn't know about taking a blanket. When I got cold, the nurse gave me a fleece throw that a former patient made and donated. She attached a tag that said "I have sat in your chair." It meant a lot to me. I felt such a connection to that woman, though I'll never know who she is. Cinda
